timeline.message: Adds parseFlattenSpec, updates tests and helper functions

timeline.author: sebastien-rosset

replies.bodyText: Thanks for the catch. This typo has been corrected.
replies.author: spacether

timeline.bodyText: boolean instead of Boolean? Don't think we actually need an object here
timeline.author: TiFu

replies.bodyText:
This has been changed to type boolean
True we don't need an object but having it named conveys that we are checking that a schema isNotExtractedInlineSchema. This helps us understand the meaning of the code vs what it is doing.
replies.author: spacether

timeline.bodyText: Call TestUtils.parseSpec instead of reimplementing parsing here?
timeline.author: TiFu

replies.bodyText: The long term intention is to deprecate, possibly remove, or change the location of parseSpec. For that reason these functions should be independent of each other.
replies.author: spacether

replies.bodyText:
The long term intention is to deprecate, possibly remove, or change the location of parseSpec.

Not true. We will still need parseSpec for current and future classes which operate on "raw" spec files.
replies.author: jimschubert

replies.bodyText: Sorry, I meant my long term intention, not ours. @jimschubert classes which operate on raw files aren't something that I know about. What are some examples? Are they not being tested right now?
replies.author: spacether

replies.bodyText: InlineModelResolver, and as mentioned in your other PR, I will be reworking Spec processing using a transformer pipeline which will need this too.
replies.author: jimschubert

replies.bodyText: Thank you for clarifying that. That other use case is newer and is not yet in the code path. Per that conversation in the other PR this issue: #843 documents the spec processing.
replies.author: spacether

replies.bodyText: parseFlattenSpec has been updated to call parseSpec because we need to keep parseSpec as a public util
replies.author: spacether

timeline.bodyText: Be careful when refactoring things like this. While YAML (as used in this method) may process schemas in a consistent order, JSON does not have a determinate order on object properties.
timeline.author: jimschubert

replies.bodyText:
Thank you for sharing that json and yaml are processed differently; I didn't know that. Do you want me to change this back to our old testing style so it will work if we swap in json in the future?
Maybe we should add a method checkJsonYamlCollectionPresence(list1, list2)
with a comment:
// YAML may process items in a consistent order, JSON does not have a determinate order on items
replies.author: spacether

replies.bodyText: Or optionally I could cast them to sets and check equality of the sets.
replies.author: spacether

replies.bodyText: This check has been changed to use List.containsAll to check presence rather than order.
replies.author: spacether

timeline.author: jimschubert
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -28,6 +28,30 @@
 
 public class TestUtils {
 
+    /**
+     * Helper method for parsing specs as a generator would be presented at runtime (inline models resolved, flattened).
+     *
+     * @param specFilePath The path to the specification file
+     * @return A processed OpenAPI document
+     */
+    public static OpenAPI parseFlattenSpec(String specFilePath) {
+        OpenAPI openAPI = parseSpec(specFilePath);
+        // resolve inline models

timeline.bodyText: What is the point of this for loop? Why can't you just do composedSchema.getName() to get this schema's name? I think this needs a comment because it could be a pretty large performance impact on huge schema documents.
timeline.author: jimschubert

replies.author: spacether

replies.bodyText: I see. No need to change, as I suspect ModelUtils will change pretty heavily by 5.0 anyway.
replies.author: jimschubert

timeline.message: Changes to List.containsAll to check presence not order
Switches two tests to use containsAll
Updates another test to use containsAll
